text:
"Interesting."  I can see why other reviewers were disappointed, however, this recipe has potential!  I think the problem is the amount of paprika.  It overpowers both the honey and the mustard.  Try reducing it by half, at least.

I used dijon mustard by the way.  The chicken was tender (I let it bake the full 45 minutes, gas oven.)  This recipe is quick to prepare and tastes upscale for a mid-week meal.  I am definitely going to make it again.

text:
If you are looking for a delicious,quick and easy chicken recipe this one is it!!!  The only suggestion I have is use a small baking dish and cover with foil until you turn and baste, then return to oven uncovered.  I found this helped keep the chicken moist and flavorful!!!  This is a new family FAVORITE!!!  We have even used the sause recipe on Pork - awsome.

text:
Yummy, Yummy, Yummy!!  If you love Honey Mustard, this recipe is for you!  I marinated my chicken for 3 hours and added more sauce than recommended, which proved to be fruitful for the flavor of the chicken.  (Marinating overnight is even better!)  I also, like others before me, used 1/2 dijon mustard and 1/2 regular mustard.  I also used soft flavor/tasting honey to make sure the mix wouldn't be too sweet.  It would be nice to have the chicken taste a bit more tangy and maybe lemon juice would be helpful.  My husband and dinner guests gobbled this up!  :)

What a quick and easy way to prepare chicken! My husband is VERY fussy and really liked this recipe.  I am going to try the recipe with Dijon, but I found the prepared mustard was just fine.  We also tried this chicken in an alternate way - 
After letting the chicken cool, slice into thin strips and serve in a salad with lettuce, grated chedder cheese, mushrooms, pineapple chunks and honey-dijon salad dressing - a great Honey Mustard Chicken salad!!

text:
I've been making Baked Honey Mustard for years and suggest 2 changes to this recipe.  First off..use dijon mustard instead of yellow.  You can also buy prepared Honey Dijon dressing or mustard if you are in a rush. The next tip is to marinate your chicken breasts in the Honey mustard. Its best to marinate overnight but in the morning is fine too.

text:
My husband and I really like this dish.  It makes a very good honey mustard sauce.  I definitely recommend using dijon mustard.  Also, pierce the chicken on both sides and marinade in the sauce for at least 30 minutes before cooking.  I poured just a little of the sauce over the stuffing I served with it.  This dish would be very good on the grill, too.  Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
This was fantastic.  The chicken came out so juicey and almost melts in your mouth.  I love the sauce it was tangy and sweet, just perfect.  I did change a few things.  I used dijon mustard and organic honey, I didn't use basil.  This was what I did.  I sprinkled salt, pepper and garlic powder on both sides of the chicken, then poured half sauce over chicken and baked for 20 minutes.  I then turned the chicken over and poured the remaining sauce over the chicken.  I baked it for another 15 minutes.  Fabulous, this is going to be a staple in my house.  My husband loved it too.  I served it with sauted spinach and garlic and conscious and lentils. This is a must try recipe.

text:
I had two chicken breasts thawed (seasoned with salt/pepper and garlic powder) - and wanted to try a new recipe.  I came across this recipe and decided to give it a try.  I changed this recipe for serving size for 2 - and made a couple of changes.  Per others comments, i only added a dash or two of basil (perfect).  I also used Dijon mustard (i dont think i would have liked it with yellow mustard).  I added about a tsp of brown sugar - and a tsp of worcestershire!  baked 20 min on one side - 10 on the other!  perfect!!  I served on top of rice with broccoli and a side salad!  It seemed it almost had a hint of an asian flavor to it.  Next time i may serve with some pineapple!  mmm..my boyfriend LOVED it...i think he could have had another serving!

Display Name:

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved this recipe!
I'm always glad that I read reviews before I try out recipes for myself. 

As others had suggested, I used half regular mustard and I used half grainy dijon. If it were up to me I would have used all dijon but I wasn't sure if my boyfriend would appreciate that or not. I also used half the amount (1/4 cup) of honey and 1/4 cup of maple syrup! Mmmm the maple and the dijon was deeelicious! I pierced my chicken on both sides and let it marinate for 2 hours. Longer would have been great too!

1 teaspoon of paprika is, as others have said, way too much. I just put a few dashes. 

And on top of everything, I used a smaller baking dish so that the chicken was fully surrounded by the sauce. This meant that my chicken was SUPER moist! With every single bite that I took I kept saying how amazed I was at how moist it was!

Lastly, Once it was done I decided to crank on the broiler and let it quickly get golden brown while I basted it. All I had was a really small baking dish so my chicken was crammed in and pracitcally boiled in the honey mustard sauce so it didn't have a chance to brown at all. But the broiler did the quick trick of making it look (and taste) delicious!

My boyfriend LOVED it! If I didn't already have something taken out for dinner tonight I would make it again already!

Half way through devouring our meal I realized I should have taken a picture for the website but..oh well!

All in all, delicious! loved it!

text:
We LOVED this! My boyfriend picked it out because he loves mustard sauces and I thought it would just be okay since I'm not crazy about mustard. But we were both very impressed. The spices really balance the mustard & honey flavors. The only change I made was to reduce the honey a little bit because I didn't want it to be too sweet, and to use dijon mustard. Thanks for the great recipe!

Addition: the next day, I sliced up the leftover chicken and tossed it with spinach, tomato, avocado, and yellow bell pepper. the sauce was a great salad dressing!

text:
This is a very easy and delicious recipe made with staple ingredients found in most kitchens. I took the advice from some of the other reviews and marinated the chicken a couple hours before baking. I also covered the dish for the first 30 min.I also only used a 1/4 tsp of basil, it was plenty. Some reviewers hated this recipe and I was at first wary of making it. I think a lot depends on the kind of mustard you use. I used a dark mustard,(Deep South) b/c that's what I had. I'm not sure I would like the taste of a yellow mustard in this recipe.I'd have to try it. This recipe went great with mashed potatoes and green beans. You can use the sauce for the mashed potatoes.

text:
o.k., this is one of my all time favorite chicken dishes. Instead of the parsley, basil, and paprika, (I was out of 2 of those), I only added Italian seasoning to the honey/mustard mixture, (just sprinkled a fair amount in, didn't measure), and it was fantastic! I cooked the chicken in 2 glass baking dishes (large family), and kept covered with foil the whole time, even after turning, until done. The chicken came out nice and tender and very tasty. I also just salt and peppered the chicken after putting them in the baking dish, instead of before hand, and just peppered the other sides after turning to avoid over salting. I will deffinately want to make this again. Yum!

text:
This is very reminiscent of the (fried) Lemony Chicken with Artichoke Hearts elsewhere on this site.  BOTH are keeper recipes! Taking a cue from other reviews, I would suggest that: (a) before pouring it onto the chicken, place the honey-mustard mixture in the fridge for 15 min to make it stiffer so that it does not flow off the chicken breast before or during baking; (b) for anyone with an instant-read thermometer, the fact that chicken breast is done when its internal temp reaches 155Â°F is perhaps a more helpful indicator of doneness than awkwardly checking that "the chicken is no longer pink and the juices run clear". Thanks, Mary, for this outstanding recipe!

text:
Absolutely the best honey mustard chicken recipe I have ever prepared myself.  I also added a pinch of garlic powder to enhance it further!!!

Note: It is now June of 2011 and this was the very first all recipes recipe I saved to my inbox in March of 2000, over 11 years ago! I like to try new recipes so I haven't revisited this one until recently and, I can see why I rated it high. The flavor of Honey and mustard is unmatchable - whether its on a soft pretzel or on chicken. As before, I used dijon mustard (far superior for that kick) and did go easy on the paprika. I think the secret for me was a stoneware baking sheet. I used bone in and skinless chicken breasts and they stayed moist flavorful. Use a meat thermometer and don't go a degree over done!

text:
This chicken turned out so very good! It requires few ingredients, and is very low in fat too! I only used 2 fairly large chicken breasts, but I kept the sauce amount the same because we like having extra sauce. I used a small 8x8 inch baking dish. These were perfectly done at exactly 45 minutes. I also just eyeballed the paprika, I used a little less than a teaspoon, and I also chopped up some fresh parsley. The sauce really is a wonderful glaze with great flavor. Next time, I'm going to try using a spicy brown mustard such as Gulden's. I bet even a dijon would be great with this also. Thanks for sharing, I will make this again for sure :)

text:
This is an awesome recipe. I've made it as is, and with modifications that other reviewers have suggested. 

As is, this recipe is a 4 star recipe. What I do to make it 5 star, is use dijon mustard instead of prepared and use fresh herbs over dried. It makes an amazing amount of difference. 
I noticed some people find the paprika overpowering, but I think it's fine as is, when used in combination with fresh herbs. Happy cooking!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1743413.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simply fantastic!!! So easy to prepare, and the taste is heavenly! I added a little curry powder, the same amount as the paprika...I don't know if it enhanced the taste, but it was delicious! I substituted 1/3 of the mustard with Dijon. Also put 2 tbls. melted butter into the baking dish to create a little more juice. I baked for 25 minutes covered with tin foil, then removed...basted with the remaining mustard sauce...mixing some of it into the butter, for another 20 minutes. When finished baking I poured the butter and mustard drippings into a fry pan, added a dash of garlic salt...threw in some peeled raw shrimp and scallops and sauteed for 4 minutes, and served on a bed of rice. Drizzle remaining glaze over the rice. OMG!!! Your guests will be begging for this recipe!!! Highly recommend this dish. Serve with steamed broccoli, and a lettuce of your choice with an Asian Sesame dressing.

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this by making foil packages for each chicken breast and pouring sauce onto the chicken. It was really fast this way which is why I went that route. The sauce was very good but I used good honey and spicy brown mustard which is what my family likes, so I'm not surprised we liked it. The basil and parsley were nice but I did halve the paprika after reading some reviews and overall I found a good tasty balance. Lots of sauce for 4 small chicken servings, next time I'll use bigger chicken breasts and marinate them.

This was just ok for us.  As it was a beautiful spring day, we grilled rather than baking, but other than that I followed the recipe (and decided to rate anyway because, if anything, I figured the grilling would add even MORE flavor).  I let the chicken marinade for about 45 min before grilling and doubled the sauce (for 2 breasts) and kept 1/2 back for dipping. It was nice, but not a *do over*, hence the "4".  It's def worth a try, though!  TY for submitting!

text:
This recipe is quite good.  I made it tonight with a few changes...as per the advice of some other reviewers, I omitted the basil.  The mustard I used was quite strong, so I cut the amount in half, but I think I will use the full amount next time.  I allowed the chicken to marinate for about an hour, and it came out tender and juicey.  Also, I added an egg and some mayo to the  mustard/honey mix to help combat the runny-ness problem that others complained about.  It helped.  I would definately make this again.

text:
To make the chicken stretch, I cut it up after baking and made a salad with it.  It was SOOO good -- moist and flavorful!  I used really good quality stone ground dijon mustard.  For the salad, I used mixed baby greens with herbs, feta, toasted almonds, roasted sunflower seeds, and fresh ground pepper, and tossed with all natural honey mustard vinagrette (the kind with real honey instead of HFCS).  I just had some leftovers for lunch, and I'm already scheming to make it again for next week!

This is a great recipe!  My husband declared that we can "add it to the rotation".  It had a perfect balance of honey and mustard.  Very easy to make!  The only things I will do differently next time will be to marinade the chicken in the sauce for awhile to intensify the flavor, and make extra sauce.  We put the sauce on baked red potatoes and it was wonderful!

It's a versatile recipe which you could add many different spices and it would still come out great.

Display Name:
SUSEYBLUE

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Quick & easy, but was still lacking something in the taste dept. 

I made it with whole grain Temeraire dijon (the 'funny taste' people must've used hot dog mustard; that sounds vile), good Hungarian paprika, tarragon in place of basil & parsley (I prolly wouldn't use herbs again; it just doesn't seem a good match as it was overpowered- rosemary might've worked), minced shallots (tip: buy shallots in bulk at your International market, they are about 1.50 a lb.), & raw Syrian honey. 

I thickened the sauce at the end (after adding the cornstarch slurry some of y'all have recommended); also 1 c. chicken stock to extend the sauce.

As I mentioned, it seemed as though it needed something, so I replaced the breasts in the sauce after thickening a bit, & hybridized this recipe with the 'Alice' chicken above- strips of crisp (but not too crisp) bacon, & melted mozzarella cheese on top of the breasts, quickly broiled.

NOW it was good! The salty, crisp bacon & creamy cheese were a perfect foil for the piquancy of the mustard & the sweetness of honey  (Served with rice, as some have said). It was a hit with husband & teen daughter, & baby ate chicken with all the 'stuff' scraped off ;).

I'd make it again (modified, as I have done.)

text:
This was a great quick meal! The honey mustard recipe is awesome! I think it's comparable to "Boars Head Honey Mustard". I used just under 1/2 cup of Dijon, then topped rest off with yellow mustard, and I followed the recipe from there. 

I cooked 2 large chicken breasts that I had cut in half long ways to have total of 4 chicken breasts. (I used the same cooking instructions listed for 6 chicken breasts). I made the full amount of Honey Mustard so I could have leftovers :) The chicken turned out great it did not dry out. An over all hit with my husband. 

**The next day I shredded the leftover chicken breast drizzled a little extra honey mustard on top then put it in a tortilla wrap with lettuce. YUM!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/952929.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Tried this tonight and was very well pleased with the result.  The sauce was easy to put together.  I used mostly prepared mustard but at suggestion of other reviewers, added some Dijon mustard as well. I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs which I marinated for a couple of hours in the sauce.  When I turned the chicken over after baking about 20-25 minutes (adjusted time down because of using smaller pieces), I found that there was a lot of juice, with the chicken bubbling happily away in it.  I turned the chicken over and poured off most of that sauce.  I did think about whether to do that but the end result was perfect so I think I made the right decision. I then spread the other half of the honey mustard sauce over the chicken and put it back in the oven for about 15-20 minutes.  It was perfect when I took it out - coated nicely with thickened sauce and browned. The chicken was moist and flavorful.  I had made extra sauce because of marinating it so I boiled what I used for the marinade, a rolling boil, to make it safe to use on the chicken while baking and to eat with the chicken. The dish tasted as though I really fussed, but it was very simple to make - and with ingredients that I had on hand.  Thank you for sharing this recipe.  I will make it again.

My husband wasn't a huge fan, but he hates any type of mustard.  His opinion doesn't count.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe tastes great, takes very little effort, and lends itself well to different cooking methods and ingredient tweaks. I generally halve the paprika, use dijon mustard, and cut back a bit on the honey (I use equal amounts dijon and honey by weight rather than volume, and honey weighs more); a splash of lemon juice can help if it tastes a bit bitter, but isn't necessary. I use four chicken breasts, pounded slightly, so I also cut down on the cooking time a bit. They get nicely caramelized on the grill (good for sandwiches), but are saucier when baked (good over rice). Either way I definitely recommend marinating for a few hours because it makes everything much more flavorful.

This was a hit with us. I covered the chicken with foil for the first thirty minutes of baking to ensure it did not dry out. I also chopped up a small sweet onion and scattered it all over the top and added a little garlic. I think without this addition I would have only given the recipe a 4 out of 5.  The next day, I used the leftover chicken and onions to make chicken wraps, yummy.  I absolutely love mustard and was looking for a way to cook with paprika since I have never used this spice in the past. This is sweet, tangy, and just what I was looking for -- thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/183119.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wow- this was fabulous!  This resulted in super tender juicy chicken and was SO EASY!  I used only 4 chicken breasts with the original sauce yield, and baked it in an 8x8 glass dish.  I left it covered for the first 20-25 minutes, then uncovered for about 40.  The only other changes I made was to 1) use about 3/4 cup DIJON mustard, 2) used the same amount of fresh local honey and decreased the paprika to about 1/2 teaspoon.  I reserved about 1/2 the sauce prior to baking for a dipping sauce when serving it- but the chicken simply did not need to be dipped in anything!  It was fantastic!  This sauce would be great over rice or used to marinate other things! Yum!

text:
Great recipe! I used bone-in thighs and legs instead of boneless chicken breasts, since we eat chicken breasts most of the time. I increased the cooking time to 55 minutes to account for the different type of chicken. This was the most tender chicken ever! I put tinfoil in the botton of the baking dish so that the honey-mustard wouldn't bake to the bottom and scooped up the remaining mixture so that we could dip the chicken into the honey mustard. The honey-mustard itself was the perfect blend of sweet and tangy. I will definitely be making this again.

text:
I was hesitant to try this recipe due to a lot of mixed reviews but I went for it and I'm so happy I did. My husband and I both liked it very much. The only changes I made was I omitted the basil and parsley and I halved the paprika. I really don't understand all of the bad reviews because a recipe with that much honey and mustard is obviously going to be sweet and tangy. I can't understand why so many people were surprised by the flavor. It tasted sweet and tangy, exactly as I expected. This is not a "knock your socks off" kind of recipe but it was yummy, affordable, quick and easy so it gets an A in my book. I will definitely make it again!

text:
I added a quarter cup of dry white wine and a few drops of lemon juice, while reducing the amount of honey a slight amount, then let marinade overnight after salting and peppering thin breast filets.
Grill marks for taste, then bake for the allotted time, and all will be fine. I served with par-boiled carrots chunks, wide chopped potatoes and medium chopped parsnips, also in the marinade. My husband was pleased that he had a roast meal in the middle of the week that had zing and character- so much so that when I turned around, he had cleared my plate too!

text:
Very good.  Just an FYI a lot of people reviewing this recipe seem confused.  Prepared mustard is not yellow mustard.  It is dijion or other mustard that has had seasoning added to it.  This recipe is not supposed to be made with plain yellow mustard.  If you use prepared mustard there is plenty of mustard flavor to the dish.

country:

text:
This is easy to prepare and tastes pleasant, but I agree with other reviewers that it needs a little work. I omitted salting and peppering the chicken, and just added a good bit of black pepper to the sauce. I also substituted dijon mustard. Cooked uncovered as the recipe suggests, but it turned out drier and tougher than most of my chicken recipes that way. I'd recommend either covering it as others have mentioned, or adding lemon juice or wine to the sauce to make it more acidic and keep the chicken more tender. Still, it was pretty good served with couscous and steamed vegetables.

text:
This is one of our favorites. I would say I follow the recipe but I never measure anything. When chicken is done I remove it from the baking dish turn up the heat and put the dish back in for a minute to thicken the remaining sauce as it is quite watery from all the juice of the chicken , then spoon it over the chicken for even more flavor. Usually serve with herb roasted veggies because the can go in first then cook together.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We grilled this instead of baked and used only chicken breasts but made the same amount of sauce and used the leftover sauce for dipping. We didn't use any of the called for spices, instead, we used a 1/2 ts of minced garlic, 1 ts of worchetershire, and a 1/4 ts of ginger. The sauce had too much of a mustard bite to it, so next time I think we will only use 1/3 cup mustard and maybe add some brown sugar. We also brushed the sauce on some fresh pineapple that we grilled and that was even better than the chicken! Overall, fast and very easy and pretty tasty with some adjustments. Will make again.

text:
I wish I were as good a cook as some people here are.  This was easy to prepare, soothed the palate better than a fine wine, and reminded me why I tend not to cook Good Stuff anymore:  my wife snaps it up faster than a starved dog.

I recommend this highly to anyone who wants a pure taste sensation without having to spend a lot of money or time at the supermarket.

Contrary to previous reports, I did not find the basil overwhelming, but everyone's different.  I did not use dijon mustard, just Plockman's.  Worked for me.

text:
A new favorite!! I recommend marinating it for a few hours, covering with tin foil for the first half then baking it uncovered, using half the paprika recommended, and using dijon mustard instead of yellow to get more flavor. I used clover honey. It would be great in salads but I just serve it with some rice. Excellent recipe, satisfied even my picky eaters :)

Display Name:
Laura Sublette Greer

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/768176.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok I admit I read others reviews of this first.  I marinated the chicken for about 30 minutes  because of what others said.  I cooked it in an 8 inch by 8 inch square pan since I made it for 2 people instead of 6 but I didn't cut anything else out except for less chicken and only 1/2 teaspoon of paprika.  I added 1 teaspoon of garlic powder, 1 teaspoon of onion powder and 2 tablespoons of soy sauce in with the other spices.  Dumped everything in the cooking pan after marinating, cover it for 30 minutes with foil, then uncovered it for the final 15 minutes.  It was delicious!  I also had it over fried rice with biscuits and green beans on the side.  Great, easy recipe!

text:
Spectacular recipe, but it needed a few fixes. I followed another reviewers suggestions and reduced the paprika to a scant 1/2 teaspoon and used Dijon mustard. I also omitted the dried parsley, as I didn't have any, and used sweet basil instead of regular. I cut the chicken into smaller, more bite-sized, pieces and kept an eye on it in the oven. My family raved about it! I served it with Chef John's Asparagus Souffle. Great combo!

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't think it matters that much what kind of mustard (I used spicy brown mustard) you use as the honey cuts down the mustard-y taste. I also cut down the paprika amount as suggested by another reviewer but again I don't think it made that much difference. I also took the suggestion to cover the dish with foil for the first 30 min which I think was a mistake. I felt that it prevented the honey mustard mixture from "baking" onto the chicken. Don't know if the mixture was suppose to end up that runny. Not sure if I'll make this again but if I do I'm just going to follow the exact recipe but maybe marinate the chicken in the mixture for a bit.

I made this recipe exactly as stated, and it was just okay. However, my nephew really liked it and specifically requested it the next time he was coming for the weekend, so this time I marinated the chicken in the glaze overnight before baking, and covered the glass dish with tin foil for most of the cooking time in a smaller pan to help hold in the juices. I also upped the amount of spices a bit and used Dijon mustard. My nephew, who is 11 by the way haha, suggested that I try this chicken in the crock pot and shred it and serve over rice or mashed potatoes. Maybe I will! Smart kid, takes after his aunt.

text:
After getting sick of making the same recipes regularly I found this fast and easy chicken recipe to be exactly what we were looking for!  The BEST past of this recipe is how easy it is to prepare!  I used 1 1/2 lbs chicken tenderloins and marinated them in the sauce after adding garlic to the recipe. Baked them for 30 minutes at 350 after 1 hour of marinating, and I threw the sauce and the chicken into the 11x7 pan.  It tasted beautiful.  Next time we are going to pair this with some wild rice because the sauce makes a ton if you're using tenderloins and we could have easily made a casserole.  Perfect for weeknights!  Perfect for weight friendly main dishes!

text:
Wow! That was delicious! I subbed dijon mustard for yellow and omitted the paprika (allergies) and it was amazing.  I had 6 rather large pieces of chicken so it filled a 9x13 pan and the chicken was pretty well covered with the marinade even though I reserved half of it.  I covered it with foil for the first half and left it uncovered for the 2nd half of the cooking.  Because the pieces were so big it took closer to an hour to bake.  Yum! I will be making this for my family again as well as taking it when I deliver meals for life events.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband and I loved this recipe. It was delicious and super easy to make. I did a few things differently, as people suggested in the comments. I marinated it first for 30 minutes (poked holes in the chicken with a fork). To marinate it I doubled the sauce/spice recipe (but only had 3 large pieces of chicken). Except the paprika I kept at 1 teaspoon since some people said it was overpowering in its original ratio. Then I still cooked it for 30 minutes one side and 10 on the other. The only problem with marinating is that it wastes a lot of honey and mustard. You need a lot to fully cover the chicken, but then it ends up just getting tossed out after cooking.

text:
This recipe was not what I expected.  It was very tender and moist, especially when you bake it covered with foil for the first 30 minutes.  But it wasn't the strong honey mustard flavor I was looking for, which is odd seeing at it has both honey and mustard for the sauce.  If you go into this recipe expecting a honey mustard flavor you may be disappointed.  But if you go into this recipe wanting a flavorful, tender chicken experience it wasn't bad at all.

userID:
7410817
Display Name:
red_fish
isPro:

followersCount:
0

2

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/714271.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used our fancy chipotle mustard, added onions to the bottom of the (foiled) baking pan, garlic powder to the marinade, chopped potatoes, a chipotle pepper and halved the paprika amount.  This recipe will work with many different types of mustards, but yellow might be too bland. I marinated for around an hour.

We served over brown rice and I made the sauce for 4 servings but only used 3 chix breast halves.  I didn't mess with the honey amount and b/c of the chipotle pepper, the sauce wasn't too sweet.

We will definitely repeat.  I baked the chix and potatoes covered in foil for 30 mins, flipped the chicken pieces, covered again and cooked for another 15. Then took the chix out of the pan and covered in foil to let set. Raised temp to 425* and covered/baked the potatoes for around 10 mins.

text:
I'm always looking for new ways to make chicken and since my hubs is a honey mustard fanatic, I thought this one would be great.


I didn't have enough honey to make 1/2 cup. I only had about 1/4 cup, and I also added 1/2 tsp garlic powder and the sauce tasted perfect and had just the right amount of sweetness. I had three bone in breast's so I upped the oven temp to 375 and layered the chicken on a bed of onions as well. It smelled so yummy while cooking and tasted great too. Hubby gave it a double thumbs up!

This was divine!  Very simple and quick to prepare, I stuck pretty close to the recipe as written, the only changes being I used 5 chicken drumsticks with bone and skin, added a few cloves of chopped garlic to the sauce, used red pepper instead of paprika (all I had) and used fresh herbs rather than dried.  I used the grey poupon country dijon style mustard and it turned out great - sweet and spicy and sticky and wonderful.  I will DEFINITELY be making this again.  Thank you!

text:
I'd say this recipe is just ok; although my bf really enjoyed it.  While I had had enough before finishing the 1st helping, he had 2 helpings.  The chicken was very moist and flavorful (it was good, definitely not disgusting), it just wasn't a flavor that I wanted too much of.  The only changes that I made were: cutting the paprika in half and using only 1/3c. of Dijon mustard.  I agree with other reviewers that the basil and parsley were too much.  I may try this one again as a base with some tweaking, but in the meantime, I think I will continue to look for another recipe.

text:
Loved this recipe!!! It had the perfect amount of sweetness and tangyness from the mustard that made this into a wonderful dish! I added some freshly crushed garlic and fresh basil to the marinade. I put skewers through the chicken cutlets, let it marinate for about 4 hours and the grilled them! It was a big hit in our family (usually anything that is on a skewer gets eatten!) A personal preference - I like this recipe better than the onles that call for honey and soy sauce - because this recipe (honey and mustard keeps the chicken cutlets as a light color after grilled. I don't like how the sot sauce "stains" the cutlets to a deeper/darker brown color, looking like dark meat.) This recipe is a sure keeper!

After reading the reviews, I decided to make 8 chicken breasts (it was for company) and I used 1/2 cup of honey with 1/2 cup of Dijon mustard and I omitted the basil altogether as it does not belong with the rest of these ingredients.  I poured half of the sauce on the chicken and turned the breasts over after about 22 minutes of baking and added the other half of the sauce.  My total bake time was 45 minutes at 350 degrees and the chicken was moist and flavorful-my company really enjoyed it.

text:
This was different.  Great taste and easy to make!  I did make some changes, however.  I used whole grain dijon mustard and I cut up a whole chicken and doubled the sauce.  I didn't add the parsley flakes since I didn't have any on me but what I did do was marinate the chicken in 3/4 of the sauce for 2 1/2 hours.  I then poured the rest of the sauce in and covered the chicken while baking.  I baked it for 30min, turned over the pieces, and baked again for 45min.  I let it stand for 10min and voila!  Served over hot rice.  Thanks!

Great!  We eat a lot of honey mustard dishes and this had a wonderful new flavor twist for us. Must be the spices. I used Grey Poupon and 4 breasts which made the perfect amount of sauce for me. The chicken was very moist too. This will be part of my regular recipes from now on.

text:
This recipe was ok, but not the greatest.  
I also used Dijon mustard, but for us the mustard taste was a little 
overpowering.  My kids did not care for it, but my husband liked it.  
I tasted the sauce before pouring it over the chicken and it was good,
 but I think it became much stronger during the cooking process.
Maybe the taste would be better using 1/2 dijon mustard 1/2 regular mustard.  Also maybe a little water or chicken broth could be added to lighten the taste.
If I make this again, I will reduce the amount of sauce.

text:
Found this recipe last minute, craving some honey mustard chicken and it did not disappoint! I'll definitely be making this again in the near future. I did however tweak the recipe a little, I opted for dijon mustard instead of the yellow, went with half the amount of paprika, (I was going for sweet without that overpowering kick), and also poured in a little extra honey. The chicken was delicious, it came out so juicy and tender! I'd say this is a must try for a quick easy dish.

text:
Delicious, quick and easy to make!

I didn't have honey on hand, so I used pure maple syrup. I also used dijon mustard instead of regular mustard. As others suggested, I marinated the chicken in half of the marinade for about 8 hours. I cooked the chicken for 30 minutes, flipped the breasts and brushed them with the leftover marinade, and cooked for another 10 minutes per instructions. This made for  flavorful, juicy chicken breasts without a lot of fat and calories.

text:
I used half Dijon and half yellow mustard, as others had, and this made a great honey mustard. Instead of breasts, I used chicken tenders. I brushed with the HM as directed; cooked for ~7 minutes @ 425F then flipped,  brushed with HM and cooked for another ~7 minutes.
There was plenty of the dressing left. As I had not separated the batch before dipping my raw-chicken-juice brush in it, I put the remaining dressing on the stove over medium low heat and brought to a simmer, adding the pan juices once the chicken cooked. Made for a delicious dipping sauce/dressing!

country:
None
text:
This recipe is great as a base recipe, but definitely needs some loving attention to perfect. Here are the changes I made:

I doubled both the honey and mustard, ditched the paprika for a teaspoon of red pepper flakes, kept the parsley, but added a teaspoon of garlic powder as well, then heated the sauce in a saucepan on low for better blending. I lined my pan with foil, laid down the chicken breasts and sprinkled them generously with sea salt and black pepper before pouring the sauce over the chicken, and sealing with more foil. Bake at 350 for 45 minutes, basting every 15 minutes and turning halfway through. Delish!

userID:
9340771
Display Name:
Janet
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
20
favoritesCount:
363
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I haven't made honey mustard chicken before, so I browsed the recipes and liked this one due mostly to it's simplicity.  I was only making for two of us, so used 2 breasts which I cut in half to make uniform-sized pieces.  I only reduced the sauce a little bit.  I did follow suggestions from other reviewers and added garlic, chili powder, 2 fat tablespoons of soy sauce, a mix of regular and brown mustard,  and then marinated the chicken for about an hour.  I followed the baking instructions - covered the casserole dish with foil and baked 30 min.  While that was going on, I cooked a sweet onion in butter until very soft, and deglazed the pan with about 1/4 cup chicken broth.  When it was time to take out the baked chicken and turn it, I gently spread the cooked onions over the breasts, drizzled the onion broth/butter into the casserole pan, then spooned the reserved sauce over all this.  Baked, uncovered, for another 15 min.  Served with brown rice and salad.  I wanted a thinner sauce to pour over the rice, and this method was perfect for that.  Turned out so very yummy, I know I will be making it again soon.  Thanks for teaching me how to make honey mustard chicken!

text:
I did this recipe with chicken tenders and it came out perfect.  I didn't use the seasonings called for in the recipe.  I used one teaspoon of Italian seasoning.  And for the mustard, I used half Dijon and half regular.  You don't have to turn the tenders.  Bake for 30 minutes.  Perfect!  Yum yum yum!

text:
This recipe is amazing! My family loves it. I used a bit less paprika. Also a suggesting for cooking it: instead of baking the chicken, I baked it in a pan with a little olive oil on medium heat. It takes a bit longer to cook on low-medium heat, but it will prevent the sauce from burning so quickly because of the honey. Absolutely delicious!

text:
We liked it. Used covered 2 quart casserole dish lined with foil.  This way the sauce completely covered chicken that I sliced.  Made 3 cups of sauce. Used a bottle and a half of Dijon, half a bottle o.f frences honey mustard and 3 big scoops of honey.  Expensive!  Next time I want to try regular honey mustard from Frenches and maybe a bit of Dijon or a bottle of honey mustard dressing and doctor with Dijon. The chicken was slightly tough, sliced and cooked for 30 mins. Next time try 20  to 25 in the oven or simply simmer together on stove.

text:
Honestly, I was surprised that I liked this as much as I did.  I have never been a BIG fan of honey/mustard combinations, but I tried this because dh and I are dieting, and we needed something different to keep us motivated.  I used dijon mustard because it was all I had on hand. Everyone in the house raved about how good this was.  I liked the way the sauce looked when I mixed it up.  I only used half of the sauce.  (Saving the other half for another night.)  I did allow the chicken to sit with the sauce on it for about an hour in the fridge before I baked it.  It was tender, flavorful, and something I'm sure I'll make again.  Also, my newlywed son is always asking for good, easy recipes.  I'll pass this along to him and his new bride.  Thanks for sharing a great recipe!

text:
I ate it and did not throw it away... But i probably won't make it often if ever. 

I used Dijon mustard. I also poked the chicken and marinated overnight. I cooked only 1 chicken breast at a time (cooking for one) and placed it in a "tinfoil boat" to keep the sauce close to the chicken (also easy cleanup) and put that in a baking dish. So, I feel like I've made all the adjustments reviewers have suggested. The taste just didn't suit my palate I guess. It was ok, but after the first one I was dreading the other 3 in the fridge.

I did shred some of the chicken and I liked that a bit better. It could soak up more of the sauce I suppose and I guess I like that texture better than keeping it whole.

country:
None
text:
I liked this the first time, except for a weird taste to it (I see other reviewers noticed it too.)  I made a couple of changes to the recipe and I no longer get the weird taste.  I eliminated the paprika and parsley from the recipe and added in 1 tsp rosemary and 1/4 tsp garlic.  I also used Dijon mustard, and I let the chicken sit in the mustard mixture overnight.  The recipe turned out tasting a little less sweet, a little more savory, and again, lacked that weird aftertaste.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
delicious and very quick and easy.  i made it with (skin-on) drumsticks that'd been frozen that i defrosted that am

i used 1/2 c regular honey with 1/4c french's (yellow) and 1/4c grainy dijon mustard.  following other suggestions, used just a dash of parika - smoked paprika as that's what i had on hand.  tented with foil to bake for first 30 mins, removed foil when i turned the drumsticks over, then removed foil cover to bake for final 15 mins.  

also, marinated the drummies in the honey/mustard in a ziploc bag (refrigerated) for about 2 hours before baking.  it's an easy dish,  the house smalls great when it bakes up

served with rice and fresh salad, yummy, simple, and healthy

text:
MAJOR hit in my home, the chicken was juicy and flavorful. I advise anyone attempting this recipe to taste test your sauce and tweak it to your specific tastes (and I doubled the amount of sauce, I love sauces). Also I seasoned and lightly floured my chicken breasts, shallow fried each side just to crust the outsides, then I finished them in the oven. Just watch and make sure they don't over cook and become dry.

text:
Absolutely delicious. I use fillets and just dump all the sauce in with them (make sure you get it under them) in a smaller dish, It almost completely covers them so I can just set the timer and let them cook. I use a little less mustard and try to use stone ground dijon. I've tried it with less paprika but I really don't notice a difference. Either way, this is a family favorite. Absolutely one of the best recipes I've found here.

text:
I wanted to work with thinner pieces of chicken, so before cutting each chicken breast in half, I sliced it lengthwise.  I reduced the baking time by about 5-10 minutes, to prevent the pieces from drying out.  The recipe turned out beautifully!  I used spicy brown mustard instead of "hot dog" mustard, and the flavor blended nicely with the honey and seasoning.  I served the chicken with mashed red potatoes, and my company loved it!  I sliced up the leftover chicken breasts to serve over salad the following day.  Delicious!

text:
Great recipe, but I don't recommend making just one chicken breast as I did the first time.  If the baking dish is too big the sauce will burn when it runs off the chicken.  Best to make as many as will fill your dish.  If you can't eat it all, it's great in a chicken salad with honey dijon salad dressing the next day!

text:
I will consider this the foundation of the marinade/sauce I used last night.  Initially I stayed to the one to one ration of the honey and dijion mustard and found it to be too sweet.  2:1 was a lot better.  Adding Parsley, Paprika, salt & pepper helped added and enhanced the spice in the dijion.  Basil.. I smelled the basil and considered what was going on in the bowl.  I'm glad I kept the basil out.  Grilled and a slice of sharp cheddar. We will be using this again.

It was a little on the runny side, but not more than any other marinade.  I brushed on extra while it was on the grill.

text:
I found this recipe last week and have already made it twice. It is so incredibly easy! It has the perfect taste! Both times we scaled it down to 4 servings. After reading reviews, I think next time I will make extra sauce to put on rice or potatoes. Also excellent with steamed broccoli. My fiance is not much for cooking different recipes but he was even able to make this. (It actually turned out a little better when he made over when I made it--and I'm the cook in the family!--his sauce was a little thinner from some water left in the pan and it turned out perfect!) The chicken was so tender that we didn't even need knives! He also added fresh mushrooms the second time when he turned the chicken over. We can't wait to have it again. I have already memorized the ingredients and that's my way of knowing that it's a keeper!! Thank you so much for this recipe. It is definately one that we will be making over and over again!

I am not a honey mustard fan, but some of my family are so I made this, and WOW! I thought it was great, most of my family loved it. I mixed a combo of prepared mustards, yellow, deli and spicy. text:
This is a fine way to cook boneless/skinless chicken breasts.  The meat was very tender and juicy.  My 30 month-old ate almost half a breast, which is a ton for him. The sauce was great over rice.  I will definitely make it again, but I was wondering if the sauce is supposed to be really runny?  I only used 2 heaping tablespoons of Dijon rather than the 1/2 cup. Perhaps that had something to do with it.  Next time I will do as someone suggested and thicken the juices into a sauce with some cornstarch. Thanks for a great recipe.

I read the reviews and took everyone's suggestions. I marinated the chicken. I added 1/4 cup of mayonnaise and a splash of lemon juice.
I covered pan with foil and baked at 350 for 30 min.,removed foil,turned chicken and baked for an additional 30 min.
Chicken was very tender and tasted fantastic.
A new family favorite!

24525322
Display Name:
Kormath

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this following the given directions, but cut it in half as it would take my son and I days to eat 6 chicken breasts.  The recipe was horrible, and that's a compliment!  I used Great Value Clover Honey (in the little bear bottle) and all the honey melted off of the chicken.  There was hardly anything left on the chicken when i took it out of the oven to turn the chicken and coat it again.  All of the honey mustard sauce was in the bottom of the pan turning brown.  I turned the chicken and coated it as instructed and when i took it from the oven about 12 minutes later, there was once again, nothing on the chicken.  all the mustard sauce had melted off again. 
Not sure what i did wrong but i ended up with plain flavorless baked chicken.  I ended up putting that in the food processor and turning it into shredded chicken and added it to a salad to save dinner.
will never try this recipe again, what a waste of time and disappointment that was.  Unless someone can msg me where i screwed up maybe?
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
Made this tonight for dinner.  For 3 chicken breasts (pounded for evenness) I used 1/2 cup honey and a scant 1/2 cup of Dijon mustard.  I used exact amounts of basil, parsley, and paprika.  I thought the basil overpowered the dish and would decrease or leave it out entirely the next time.  My family enjoyed this dish and are open to trying it again with the changes.  We served it with egg noodles and green beans.  Chicken was very moist and tender; seasoned both sides with salt and pepper and poured all the sauce on top.  Flipped it over halfway through cooking.  I baked it in a glass casserole dish for 35 minutes.

text:
I always try to stick to the recipe the first time I make it. I used half Dijon mustard and half spicy/grainy yellow mustard because I did not have enough Dijon.  This is an excellent recipe because the results are grÃ©Ã¢t and it's simple to prÃ©pare. Easy to make when you get home from work or when you're to tired to cook.  Just throw it in the oven and relax.  I would definitely serve this for company.  The seasonings are very good but next time I make it, I might add a quarter teaspoon of red pepper flakes just to give it a little kick.  This also makes a lot of pan juices. To serve, I would slice the chicken and then drizzle the pan juices over.  I would serve this with a side of mashed potatoes and some green beans. Enjoyed this meal a lot.

None
text:
After reading other reviews prior to making, I took some advice - I added 1 tsp brown sugar, 1 tsp worcestershire sauce, and a little lemon juice, with HALF the paprika called for. Also, dijon mustard or honey mustard works amazing! Turned out perfect! Next time I will make the sauce in the morning and let it marinate all day - so the whole chicken breast (inside and out) tastes like the sauce, not just the skin.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pleasantly surprised. Omitted basil and parsley, I didnât have any on hand. Seasoned chicken tenderloins with salt, pepper and garlic powder then marinated using 1/2 of mixture of 1/2C spicy brown mustard, 1/2C honey and 1/2 tsp paprika for two hours before baking. Reserved other half mixture. While marinating chicken, I sautÃ©d small yellow onion, chopped and 4 cloves fresh garlic pan in a teaspoon of olive oil. Placed the chicken on top of onion and garlic mixture in 9X13 baking dish. Baked covered for 30 minutes. Flipped chicken, drained most of the juice/sauce and added the remaining honey mustard mixture. Baked uncovered 20 minutes.  Then broiled for 10 minutes, flipping the chicken halfway through. Absolutely delicious.

Really good! After marinating for 4-5 hours, I grilled these - halfway through brushing excess marinade on the cooked side after flipping. With 18 boneless,skinless chicken thighs, I used 1/4 c mustard and 1/2 c Dijon, and 1/2 c of honey with 1 & 1/2x the spices called for. Went really well with roasted asparagus with lemon pepper and "oven roasted sweet potatoes" (recipe from this website). YUM. Not too sweet, not too mustard.

text:
Love it. Changes as suggested:

less than halfcup of honey

similar proportions for a mix of dijon and honey

abt tbs of lemon juice

only salted and peppered one side of chicken

used various cuts
Put chicken on a bed of onions, carrots and small potatoes
cooked for 25mins with foil on
12 mins without  foil
and 3 mins on the broil 

result:  just the right amount of tang and sweetness. lovely darken bits also aesthetic

text:
I decided to use up a little of a honey mustard I had on hand. Worked well. I marinaded the chicken in half the sauce for a few hours, I didn't want to bake with that so I  put the chicken in a foil lined dish and poured over the remaining sauce, turned half way through cooking time. I was afraid the  taste was going to be either  overpowering on the mustard or too sweet from the honey but it passed the taste test and will be made again.

text:
I made this recipe a 2nd time which turned out better with these minor changes: 
I doubled the sauce ingredients and marinated the chicken breasts (which I cut lengthwise in half) for a couple of hours. Then I placed the chicken and all of the sauce in a 9x11 glass baking dish, and baked it for 45 minutes, no need for turning, but I did cover it with tin foil for the first 30 minutes. No fuss, no muss . . . turned out lovely with lots of sauce for the mashed potatoes. We served it with green beans. Will be making this again!

text:
This recipe is perfect when you don't have much time to cook. I prepared it for my boyfriend's roommates and we all loved it. For the sauce, I substituted a mixture of dijon mustard and sweet mustard for yellow mustard to create a more zesty flavor. I also baked the chicken in aluminum foil to keep it extra juicy! The leftover sauce mixed with a little bit of olive oil also makes a very nice salad dressing. I will definitely make this again.

I modified this receipe and it turned out great. First I reduced the amount of mustard to 1 Tablespoon and added 2 Tablespoons of lemon juice. I also added 1/2 cup of olive oil and omitted the paprika.  I let it sit overnight so that the chicken would absorb the flavour. Barbecues nicely without drying out the meat.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/169789.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We really enjoyed this. There's a Mexican restaurant in Omaha called Julio's which has served a chicken dijon recipe for years. If I added a little white wine to the sauce and thickened it up a bit possibly with corn starch, that may closely approximate the sauce in that recipe. As called for, the recipe doesn't make a lot of sauce, so if you prefer a lot of sauce, considering doubling the sauce volume. I used boneless, skinless chicken thighs and adjusted the bake time accordingly (checked after 15 to 20 minutes, flipped and applied the sauce on the other side), then baked for another  7 to 10 minutes.

userID:
16723150
Display Name:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I integrated all the suggestions made in the reviews.  I used part dijon, part grainy dijon, and part plain ol' mustard. I used about two thirds of honey and 1/3 of maple syrup. I went light on the paprika and basil.  Added a splash of lemon. 
Overall, the flavour was on point. It was far better than I was expecting it to be. It probably would have been better had I marinated it too. It was super juicy - I would recommend a small dish to ensure the chicken is immersed in the sauce.  

My only complaint is that the sauce had a low viscosity and as a result, I lost some of the yummy sauce on my chicken.

text:
We really enjoyed this recipe! I used Dijon mustard since I was out of yellow mustard. Perhaps the Dijon gives the sauce an extra tang...not sure if it really makes a difference. For paprika, I used Hungarian  paprika (sweet). Also, marinated the chicken in the sauce for an hour. I made extra sauce because I thought the chicken might need more during baking, but that was not the case at all. I ended up drizzling some of the extra sauce over steamed broccoli--delish! I think this dish would go well with honey roasted potatoes.

Measurements of all ingredients were spot on as well as cooking time, in my opinion. Easy recipe to make and will make again!

I'm not a huge fan of the honey/mustard flavor combination, so this was a pleasant surprise. Despite what seemed to me to be a good amount of honey and mustard, somehow the flavor came out fairly mild. And the breasts were cooked well enough, but still came out juicy and not dry. I ate it with wild rice on the side, which soaked up a bit of the sauce. Worth making again!

country:

text:
Very tasty! I had all ingredients on hand, so this was my choice for dinner. However, I saw many reviews stating to use Dijon mustard instead. I did not have that so stuck with the yellow.  I thought it tasted great with just yellow mustard.  
I also saw other reviews that said it came out dry. I did have 7 chicken breasts instead of the six called for, so this worried me. I ended up doubling the sauce recipe. It seemed on the sweet side, so I added 1 tsp. Worchester sauce to cut the sweetness a bit. It worked! 
After salting and peppering, I pierced the chicken with a fork a few times to allow the sauce to seep in as it was cooking.  Came out fabulous! Very tasty and not dry at all. Thank you!
4 stars only because I didn't make as the recipe stated and made a few changes.

text:
I made this exactly as stated. The taste is OK, very light and aromatic. The problem I have with this method is that the flavour does not seep into the chicken therefore when you bite in to it, it's just dry on the inside. I would probably let the chicken marinade in the ingredients overnight before baking. Otherwise though this is a nice pairing with some basmati rice.

text:
Loved it.  Easy.  Nice change to find a chicken recipe without BBQ sauce or canned soup in the sauce.  I used really plump chicken breasts and I followed the advice of others and marinated them 4 hours.  Perfect!  I also followed the cooking advice and put tin foil over pan for first 30 minutes of cooking.  Use a smaller pan to save the sauce and juices.  Use Dijon mustard for sure, plain mustard doesn't cut it.  I cut the paparika in half, and will do that again.

Yum Yum Yum! So quick and easy and flavourful! Made these and they were so moist! I am trying to use up my whole-grain mustard, so used that instead yellow mustard, but it worked out just the same! The only annoyance was that the honey left my pan with burned on sauce! It may have been that my pan was just too big for the 2 portions I did, because in the video for this recipe it looks like they have a lot of liquid in their pan after cooking. I did not, however. If I were to do this again, I would line with foil just so it was easier to clean up afterwards.

text:
I have tried few recipes from this site but I feel compelled to write about this one. I have never made honey mustard chicken before. I had a friend visiting from Australia. I wanted something simple and different. I also wanted something I could do quickly after work. We really enjoyed the the chicken. It was tasty and flavorful which was surprising as I would normally would have probably seasoned the chicken for similar recipes for at least 2 hours. 
I decided to double the ingredients and I also used the other half to do pork leg (hock) in a slow cooker with about a teaspoon of cider vinegar and 1/4 cup of balsamic vinegar on high for 2 1/2 hours and 2 hours on low with mushrooms added in the second half. That proved to be another hit. The chicken was served with salad and saffron rice. The pork with sweet potatoes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderful dish and quick + easy to prepare.

I did as a few others suggested- 
Used Dijon mustard
The only honey to trust anymore is if it has pollin in it, otherwise you just don't know.
I am a fan of white pepper. I used a full teaspoon on this and used a pinch of salt only.
only half of the paprika
Rosemary to taste
I used the skin and coated it with 1/2 of the mustard (coated with a little flour) 
then brushed it with a mixture of honey/ remaining mustard to the top reserving part for the other side.
Put the pan into the oven and finished as directed deducting the time for browning.

Best chicken ever for a quick dinner and it would work for a whole chicken if you used a meat thermometer. Great company food!

text:
I made this for dinner tonight. After reading some other tweaks I used Dijon. I didn't have dried basil, so I used dried savory 2 TBS rubbed to powder. I also added a splash of Worcestershire. I scored the chicken breasts used a baking dish so the chicken just barely fit. I put the marinade in the baking dish then rubbed the salt and pepper into the chicken then coated the breasts both sides then covered with plastic wrap and marinade overnight. The sweet savory mustard flavor was wonderful. I served with yams and vinaigrette salad. Thank you for the great recipe

text:
didn't change a thing in the  sauce. Did change way I cooked it. I did it the same way I do the Key West Chicken on this site. I pound the breast out till they are even across in thickness. About 1/2 in.
Marinate over night. Grill 6 mins. a side. Sauce seals the juices in.
I toss the marinade and make  fresh sauce for basting and dressing for noodles or rice.

I love this recipe. I have made it twice. Very surprised by the negative reviews. However, if it is not sweet enough for your taste, try using honey mustard or dijon instead of regular yellow mustard. Add half the paprika if you think it is too strong. As for the herbs, they work perfectly for me. Great recipe :)

text:
This was a hit at my house! I used bone-in chicken thighs and removed the skin. I used all the seasonings but I omitted the paprika because I didn't have any. I don't think it needed it anyway. I also added about 1 teaspoon of lemon juice. I took others' advice and baked the chicken in a small dish to keep the meat in the juices. I covered it with foil for the first 30 minutes then removed and continued basting every 10 minutes until done. It came out super juicy and everyone loved it! I will definitely make this again!

I made this for company last night. Only used 4 chicken breasts but the same amount of sauce. (It would have been enough sauce for 6 after all.) Used spicy brown mustard. Marinated the chicken in the sauce overnight and poured the whole thing into a 2-qt casserole to bake. I was honestly expecting more flavor. I neglected the salt and pepper to taste, so maybe it needed salt. My guests loved it though, so it's worth trying again with some tweaks.

text:
Ok, I made this tonight for my family. And I thought that it was ok, my husband also thought it  was ok, and my son wouldn't eat it at all my mother on the other hand loved it, and said that she could eat it every day. I used honey Dijon mustard instead of just normal mustard, and I think that made the difference. The flavor was good, the reason that I thought it was just ok was because the sauce just dripped off onto the plate. I don't mind a thin sauce, but it did not stick at all. So as long as I scooped up the sauce with every bite it was good. The other thing is, the chicken was cooked perfectly, it wasn't to dry but not to juicy.  I don't know if I will make it again, but it was not bad at all. I would give a 5 but the sauce just wouldn't stick.

text:
Overall this is a pretty good recipe.  It tastes good as is, directions were clear and it's pretty much fool proof.   This is perfect for any beginner.  I followed one suggestion and marinated this for about an hour and worked perfectly. The reason why I didn't give it five is because it did not have any wow factor for me.  I think I know the culprit...and that is using regular mustard because it was a bit overpowering. I think next time I will try Dijon mustard like others suggested and see if it bumps this recipe up to five stars.
